extension.valueMarkdown: This example of a ComparativeEvidenceReport Profile shows a report from a single observational study with 2 baseline measures, 2 participant flow measures, and 4 outcome measures.

text.div: StudyGroup: Severely Obese Adults 2018 Norwegian Cohort Cohort study with baseline data of exposures from November 2005 through July 2010 and follow-up data from 2006 until death or through December 2015 at a tertiary care outpatient center, Vestfold Hospital Trust, Norway. Consecutive treatment-seeking adult patients (n = 2109) with severe obesity assessed (221 patients excluded and 1888 patients included). (1888 participants)

entry.display: ComparatorGroup: JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study Control cohort

text.div:
Title: Norwegian Cohort Study Comparing Bariatric Surgery vs Medical Obesity Treatment for Long-term Medical Complications and Obesity-Related Comorbidities


Description: The main purpose of this study is, in combination with data from the Register and Biobank study and follow-up data from the Norwegian Prescription Database, to compare the long-term effects (4-10 years) of surgical and non-surgical treatment of morbid obesity on obesity related comorbidities by studying changes in medicine usage after treatment. Hypotheses 1. Primary hypothesis: As compared to non-surgical treatment, bariatric surgery will be associated with higher rates of remission, and lower rates of new-onset drug treated hypertension during a follow-up period of ≤ 10 years. 2. Secondary hypotheses: Changes in the usage of other drugs, particularly drugs related to obesity related comorbidities, will differ significantly between patients undergoing bariatric surgery or non-surgical treatment during the follow-up period.


Study Design: Observational research (coded as: SEVCO:01002 from https://fevir.net/sevco); Parallel cohort design (coded as: SEVCO:01011 from https://fevir.net/sevco); Longitudinal data collection (coded as: SEVCO:01028 from https://fevir.net/sevco)

entry.display: Norwegian Cohort Study Comparing Bariatric Surgery vs Medical Obesity Treatment for Long-term Medical Complications and Obesity-Related Comorbidities

text.div: As compared with medical patients, surgically treated patients were significantly younger with a higher BMI.
Mean age 41.2 in Surgical Group vs. 45.7 in Medical Group (p < 0.001)
Age in Medical Group (n = 956) mean 45.7 years, SD 13.5 years

This example expresses the variable 'Remission of diabetes' as a dichotomous variable with a definition using both definition.concept (for a SNOMED CT term) and definition.reference which references an OutcomeDefinition Profile of Group Resource. (dichotomous variable)
Risk of Remission of diabetes in control group was 14.8%.

entry.display: ComparatorOnlyEvidence: Remission of diabetes without bariatric surgery (Control Group) in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div: Risk of Remission of diabetes in intervention group was 57.5%.

entry.display: InterventionOnlyEvidence: Remission of diabetes with bariatric surgery (Intervention Group) in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div:
greater likelihood of diabetes remission: AR, 57.5% vs 14.8%; RD, 42.7% [95% CI, 35.8%-49.7%], RR, 3.9 [95% CI, 2.8-5.4]
Compared with specialized medical treatment, bariatric surgery appears to induce remission of diabetes.

entry.display: ComparativeEvidence: Bypass surgery effects on Remission of diabetes in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div: This example expresses the variable 'New onset depression' as a dichotomous variable with a definition using definition.reference which references an OutcomeDefinition Profile of Group Resource. (dichotomous variable)
Risk of New onset depression in control group was 6.5%.

entry.display: ComparatorOnlyEvidence: New onset depression without bariatric surgery (Control Group) in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div: Risk of New onset depression in intervention group was 8.9%.

entry.display: InterventionOnlyEvidence: New onset depression with bariatric surgery (Intervention Group) in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div:
greater risk of new-onset depression: AR, 8.9% vs 6.5%; RD, 2.4% [95% CI, 1.3%-3.5%], RR, 1.5 [95% CI, 1.4-1.7]
Compared with specialized medical treatment, bariatric surgery may slightly increase the incidence of depression.

entry.display: ComparativeEvidence: Bypass surgery effects on New onset depression in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div: This example expresses the variable 'Treatment with opioids' as a dichotomous variable with a simple definition using definition.concept.text (dichotomous variable)
Risk of Treatment with opioids in control group was 15.8%.

entry.display: ComparatorOnlyEvidence: Treatment with opioids without bariatric surgery (Control Group) in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div: Risk of Treatment with opioids in intervention group was 19.4%.

entry.display: InterventionOnlyEvidence: Treatment with opioids with bariatric surgery (Intervention Group) in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div:
greater risk of treatment with opioids: AR, 19.4% vs 15.8%, RD, 3.6% [95% CI, 2.3%-4.9%], RR, 1.3 [95% CI, 1.2-1.4]
Compared with specialized medical treatment, bariatric surgery may slightly increase the use of opioids.

entry.display: ComparativeEvidence: Bypass surgery effects on Treatment with opioids in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div: This example expresses the variable 'Additional GI surgical procedure' as a dichotomous variable with a simple definition using definition.concept.text (dichotomous variable)
Risk of additional GI surgical procedure in control group was 15.5%.

entry.display: ComparatorOnlyEvidence: Additional GI surgical procedure without bariatric surgery (Control Group) in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div: Risk of additional GI surgical procedure in intervention group was 31.3%. 292 out of 932 observed with percentage of: 31.3%

entry.display: InterventionOnlyEvidence: Additional GI surgical procedure with bariatric surgery (Intervention Group) in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div:
Surgical patients had a greater risk for undergoing at least 1 additional gastrointestinal surgical procedure (AR, 31.3% vs 15.5%; RD, 15.8% [95% CI, 13.1%-18.5%]; RR, 2.0 [95% CI, 1.7-2.4]).
Compared with specialized medical treatment, bariatric surgery appears to increase the rate of additional gastrointestinal surgical procedures.

entry.display: ComparativeEvidence: Bypass surgery effects on Additional GI surgical procedure in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study
